title: Tuesday, 24th October, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Morning

PM11:02am

I have a pic for today, which I can share

PM11:02am

But I also have something novel to accompany said pic

11:02 am
PM11:02am

PM11:02am

Mark Johnson

PM11:03am

and..

11:02 am
PM11:03am

PM11:03am

Hang on, dont click that

PM11:03am

Us this link

11:03 am
PM11:03am

http://ig.ft.com/audio/Johnson1.wav

PM11:03am

Its 49 seconds long -- and you have to listen right to the end

PM11:04am

It explains the Johnson verdict

11:04 am
BE11:05am

...................... "f__king Christmas!"

PM11:05am

Yeah

BE11:05am

That's a quote to remember.

11:05 am
PM11:05am

How often do traders express joy when a big order comes in?

PM11:06am

DRichi -- he might!

BE11:07am

To be fair, traders are weirdos. Socially maladjusted curiosities. They might express joy at all sorts of things a normal, functioning human being wouldn't.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

(No offence, ROTR.)

PM11:07am

Bryce!

PM11:07am

Johnson has yet to be sentenced.

11:07 am
undefined
PM11:08am

Footsie's flat

PM11:08am

Again, precious little corporate news flow

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Full report here, I should add. https://www.ft.com...-9bfb-4a9c83ffa852 ... And yes, it's a bit quiet.

PM11:08am

Few trading statements

BE11:08am

Whitbread being today's misprice.

11:08 am
PM11:08am

Oh, and Carillion seems to have avoided death, at least for now

PM11:09am

Shall we go straight to Whitbread?

BE11:09am

We can, certainly.

11:09 am
Whitbread PLC (WTB:LSE): Last: 3,748, down 194 (-4.92%), High: 3,900, Low: 3,739, Volume: 691.24k
BE11:09am

It's Costa, again.

BE11:10am

LFL's down to 0.1% in Q2, from 1.1% in Q1.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

They're pushing through a bunch of cost savings to defend margin, but sales really aren't looking good.

BE11:11am

The fixes in place are a new breakfast menu (!) that's apparently improved things by 9% in the test rollout, and a partnership with Morrison.

PM11:11am

hmm

11:11 am
BE11:11am

... which I'm guessing isn't the exclusive type, or it'll mean closing all the Costas that were put in Tesco's fallow floorspace.

PM11:12am

Someone was saying last week that there's room for another X hundred Costas in the UK. Can remember which firm it was -- not well timed.

PM11:12am

Interims here btw https://www.invest...1710240700033908U/

11:12 am
BE11:12am

That's a very common argument among the sellside. Costa and Greggs are always modeled to have the same capacity to expand as Subway and Starbucks.

BE11:13am

As if there's no cannibalisation between these four brands. As if they can all co-exist happily.

BE11:13am

Anyway, headline beats on cost phasing mostly

11:14 am
BE11:14am

But anyone holding on for a breakup for Whitbread -- a theme that went around again a month or so ago, if I remember correctly -- might be disappointed.

BE11:14am

Here's Morgan Stanley.

BE11:15am

The company says "despite the well known short term economic uncertainty, our performance in the first half was good and we expect to meet expectations for the full year." Consensus is on PBT of £589m (MSe £605m), so we expect no forecast changes after today. Recent hotel data has been a bit softer, and the Costa Q2 LfL is disappointing, so we expect to trim 1-2% off our FY18 PBT forecast. Our forecasts assume group LfL sales of 2.3% (split +3.8% Premier Inn (within which RevPAR of +2.0%, new space adds c. 5%), +1.5% Costa, and +0.5% Restaurants). On our forecasts, the shares trade on a calendarised 2018e P/E of 13.7x and 8.6x EV/, and while they have had a good run into these results, we still think they look good value given its market-leading positions, roll-out story, scope for efficiency gains, levers for improved operational performance, and a significant discount to its sum-of-the-parts.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

And Panmure.

BE11:16am

Whitbread’s valuation is not optically demanding with a PE of 15.7x (FY18) well below the five year average of 17.5x. But WTB was enjoying mid-single-digit LFL growth in Costa and earnings upgrades until 2016, after which the shares have adjusted to a more benign domestic growth trajectory. Internationally, WTB’s recent buy-out of its south China JV partner provides a useful, but slightly underwhelming, valuation
marker. The 8.8x transaction multiple implies an equity value of c.£100m for the whole of Costa China (less than 2% of market cap), suggesting International is not yet a significant value driver. On our SOTP Costa is currently valued at 9x FY18 EV/EBITDA vs. Starbucks at 13x.

PM11:16am

But hang on, the stock's off 5%

11:16 am
Whitbread PLC (WTB:LSE): Last: 3,739, down 203 (-5.15%), High: 3,900, Low: 3,739, Volume: 702.91k
BE11:17am

It is. Q2 deceleration, costs problematic. So while management is holding guidance, there's no reason for investors to agree.

BE11:18am

Numis.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

WTB now trades on a CY18E P/E of 15.0x and a stable FCF yield of 5%. While we see solid rollout potential in both brands, we are concerned that ongoing cost inflation presents downside risk to estimates, with little visibility on the group’s £150m efficiency plan

BE11:19am

And Berenberg.

BE11:19am

Our view in a nutshell: We remain attracted to the long-term growth prospects for
Whitbread, but acknowledge that the potential woes for UK businesses and consumers due
to Brexit will make for a bumpy ride. The company’s H1 2018 results released this morning delivered a 3.4% beat in terms of the underlying pre-tax profit (PTP) at £328m, however softer trends in the second quarter are likely to be the focus. We continue to rate Whitbread as a Buy with a £50 price target.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

Since FY results, Whitbread’s consensus expectations for the FY PTP has remained stable at c£588m. We are currently slightly ahead of this at £605m. With a £11m beat in H2 2018, the readacross will be that the moderation in trends may mean that FY expectations are reached, but that the growth into 2019 may come under scrutiny.

PM11:20am

So that's very much a reluctant buy recomendation

BE11:21am

Yep. One can argue that a 5% move is a lot on no explicit change of guidance and a bit of fairly obvious caution about consumer spending. But 5% moves on not much are becoming the norm, so ......

11:21 am
PM11:22am

No market structure, but nobody care

BE11:22am

Indeed. .... Oh, should just note the sector's following.

Restaurant Group PLC (RTN:LSE): Last: 293.00, down 7.1 (-2.37%), High: 300.10, Low: 290.50, Volume: 134.26k
11:22 am
Merlin Entertainments PLC (MERL:LSE): Last: 368.78, down 5.12 (-1.37%), High: 374.80, Low: 367.10, Volume: 901.56k
BE11:23am

And I'll leave the argument about lazy market pricing for another time.

undefined
11:23 am
BE11:23am

So, what else? Did you catch this Brighthouse story?

PM11:23am

I did!

PM11:23am

How many hundreds of thousands of people hit by this crew??

11:23 am
BE11:23am

FCA statement here: https://www.fca.or...s-249000-customers

BE11:24am

And FT take on it here: https://www.ft.com...-8506-11d99af23a9f

BE11:24am

The company will pay £10.1m to 81,000 customers whose ability to pay had not been properly assessed. Those who returned the goods will be paid back interest and fees charged, plus a compensatory interest at 8 per cent. Those who retained the goods will have their debts written off.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

....... now, the (absolutely grim) rent-to-buy market is a subset of the rip-off credit investigation, so we can't draw direct parallels.

PM11:25am

(There's another 180k people on top of those)

BE11:26am

However, that 8 per cent compensatory interest is quite interesting.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

It might interest investors of Provident Financial, which is also under investigation.

PM11:26am

Oooh, yes

BE11:27am

You'll remember that Provident made £70m of revenues from a PPI-ish product.

11:27 am
PM11:27am

I do -- and I remember how many years it took the regulator to wake up to the fact that it really was PPI-ish

BE11:27am

Yep. Most analysts have put in £70m times four as their compensation estimate, for the four years under investigation.

BE11:28am

But it's not capped at that. Because if Provident has to compensate for the interest charged on the fees charged for its thing that wasn't PPI, the number could get quite big.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Using the Brighthouse fine as precedent, that doesn't seem impossible.

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

PM11:30am

Do share

11:30 am
BE11:30am

ROP remains tail risk: Despite the strong operating performance in Vanquis in Q3 (yoy bookings were up 5%, customer numbers were up 13% and receivables were up 14%), the threat of redress following the outcome of the ROP investigation casts a shadow over the division. Assuming home credit recovers as we expect, we think that the group could handle fines/redress provisions of up to £300m, assuming a required CET1 ratio of 20% (Q3: 21.2%). In addition to the ROP investigation, the FCA has stated publically its commitment to helping potentially vulnerable borrowers and we think this may have further ramifications for earnings and returns.

BE11:30am

Regulatory capital could come under pressure: Post-repayment of the £120m 2012 bond, the group has £74m of free cash and £236m of headroom. Vanquis accelerated deposit taking in Q3, raising £80m (taking total deposits to £1.2bn) meaning that only a further £92m is required to eliminate the intercompany loan. Regulatory capital (Q3 2017: 21.2%) remains a concern, with IFRS9, a potential increase in capital requirements as a result of the ROP investigation/home credit restructure and the increase in the counter-cyclical buffer all reducing the company’s ability to weather a potential redress/fine.

BE11:31am

Guidance unchanged and should meet market expectations: Since FY results, Whitbread’s
consensus expectations for the FY PTP has remained stable at c£588m. We are currently
slightly ahead of this at £605m. With a £11m beat in H2 2018, the readacross will be that the moderation in trends may mean that FY expectations are reached, but that the growth into 2019 may come under scrutiny. We would not expect to change our 2018 forecasts materially, nor do we expect any significant changes to consensus.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Oh, and I see there's a "folks have to be responsible for their own actions" theme beginning on the right.

BE11:32am

The nearest Brighthouse to the FT office is in the old Elephant and Castle shopping centre .....

BE11:32am

Here's what they're rent-to-selling at the moment.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

PM11:33am

On Bright House -- one thing I wonder whether the FCA clocks is that their stated interest rate of circa 70% is way off

PM11:33am

See this

11:34 am
BE11:34am

And here's the small print on that pram.

BE11:34am

BE11:34am

(Sorry it's sideways.)

11:34 am
PM11:34am

Okay, here's another example

PM11:35am

PM11:35am

£867 telly, which will cost you £1716 over three years

11:35 am
PM11:35am

Except it's not an 867 quid telly

BE11:35am

These are the prices if you keep up repayments, which is important.

PM11:36am

It's a 600 quid telly

11:36 am
PM11:36am

Which costs 1716 over three years

PM11:36am

I can't do the API in my head, but it's not 70%

PM11:36am

See here's the telly for 600 quid

11:36 am
PM11:36am

PM11:37am

Anyway, guess we should get back to public markets

undefined
11:38 am
PM11:38am

Carillion -- this interim ceo has been busy

PM11:38am

https://www.invest...1710240700044245U/

PM11:38am

Keith Cochrane

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Hooray! They've sold the thing they were selling.

PM11:39am

Serco have no doubt got a bargain with this NHS contracts

BE11:40am

Well, maybe. £50.1m, phased.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Most of the cash to arrive in the first half of 2018.

BE11:41am

And the guidance on the disposal pool remains £300m by end 2018, so this really doesn't change anything.

BE11:42am

What does change things is its punishingly expensive new debt line.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

£40m senior secured and £100m senior unsecured revolver.

BE11:42am

That's on cash margin of 8% LIBOR for secured and 10% LIBOR for unsecured ......

BE11:43am

... stepping up to 12% post repayment of the secured notes.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Which I guess puts Carillion in the Brighthouse of corporate credit markets.

PM11:44am

hehe

BE11:45am

Here's UBS with its ever-entertaining 1p price target.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Carillion announced it has signed heads of terms for the sales of parts of its UK Healthcare facilities management business to Serco for £50.1m. The two parties will now finalise a business purchase agreement and transfer the relevant contracts in a phased manner. Carillion expects most of the cash proceeds to be received in H118. The business generated £90m of annual sales. Assuming approximately 5.5-6% average support services margins implies EBITA of £5-5.5m so an implied multiple of 9- 10x EV/EBITA, broadly in line with our overall valuation of the support services business in our SOP.

BE11:45am

The previously announced additional £140m of facilities have now been signed. In addition, the group has agreed deferral of £16m of private placement payment due in November 2017 and the option to defer £49m of PP's maturing in September 2018 until January 2019. The group is also deferring cash contributions into the pension scheme of around £24m, which would have been due between August 2017 and March 2018. The outcome of the triennial valuation remains due which could re-calibrate pension payments going forward. The cost of these new facilities / deferrals is between LIBOR + 8% and LIBOR + 12% so is relatively high.

BE11:46am

As part of the £300m disposal target, the largest part was expected to come from the disposal of the Canadian services business. It is now communicating it may retain elements of this business, suggesting forthcoming bids for the entire operation either do not exist or valuation is below expectations.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Valuation: Sell, 1p price target
Our PT is based on SOP. While facility extension and other liquidity measures provide breathing space, they do not fundamentally solve Carillion's debt problems. The disposal programme has got some traction although it appears buyers are cherry picking assets which raises a question of the quality of the remaining business. We ultimately expect significant dilution to existing shareholders and see no material equity value left for current shareholders.

Carillion PLC (CLLN:LSE): Last: 47.73, up 3.98 (+9.09%), High: 54.50, Low: 46.75, Volume: 13.70m
undefined
11:48 am
PM11:48am

What else?

PM11:48am

Bunzl mentioned earlier, but that's far too boring

PM11:48am

Hunting?

11:48 am
PM11:49am

Esure? -- that's a JPM downgrade i think, but havent seen

BE11:49am

I guess. Hunting is less boring than Bunzl, and Esure is less boring than Hunting ......

BE11:49am

Esure's a sector thing from JPM.

11:49 am
esure Group PLC (ESUR:LSE): Last: 266.20, down 8.3 (-3.02%), High: 267.30, Low: 262.10, Volume: 198.47k
BE11:50am

Likes RSA, doesn't like car insurers.

Admiral Group PLC (ADM:LSE): Last: 1,896, down 20 (-1.04%), High: 1,896, Low: 1,867, Volume: 770.10k
11:50 am
BE11:51am

UK motor pricing likely to slow, but a genuine cost is removed From a sector standpoint, the major development in recent months in UK motor has been the announcement that the Ogden rate will be revised, with the government stating that the new methodology would produce a rate in the range of 0-1%. We expect that this change will be enacted in 2018, and given that the insurance industry has lobbied hard to get the rate amended, we see this overall as a positive development.
We must acknowledge, however, that with a cost to the industry being removed, it is likely that price increases slow, or even temporarily reverse over the coming quarters. In combination we do not see this as a headwind for industry margins (it is, afterall, a cost that was being passed on), however a flatter pricing environment may at the margin result in less switching behavior, which arguably plays into the hands of those with larger direct books, such as Direct Line.

BE11:51am

Elsewhere, the wider insurance industry has seen very large losses in Q3 due to US catastrophe events, which we believe will influence not only property cat pricing, but could also filter down to larger ticket commercial lines. In our view this is positive for RSA, which has seen pricing pressure in some of its (international) UK commercial business, such as Marine. While it could be argued that the cost of RSA's reinsurance programme may also increase, overall we believe a hardening market in commercial lines will be seen as a bigger driver.

BE11:51am

So, on RSA, "2018 is likely to be the year that special dividends commence for RSA, and while its total yield may not be the highest in the sector, it may again come on the radar for income funds".

11:51 am
RSA Insurance Group PLC (RSA:LSE): Last: 634.00, up 4 (+0.63%), High: 643.50, Low: 634.00, Volume: 957.16k
BE11:52am

Admiral's dead money .....

BE11:53am

And Esure's expensive, unless there's a bid, which is a risk the note doesn't really touch upon.

11:53 am
undefined
BE11:53am

Did you see Relx has bought Comic-Con?

PM11:54am

No

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Is that how you write Comic-con? And is that how your write Relx? I'm uncertain about all of this.

PM11:55am

Ive never understood the fascination with comics

PM11:55am

As in comic comics -- no comedians, some of whom i like a lot

11:55 am
BE11:56am

Having grown up in Dundee, I'm pretty comfortable with the concept. Though I don't think anyone dresses up as Dennis the Menace to these convention things.

BE11:56am

Anyway, MCM's the company.

PM11:57am

(Ah, DC Thomson)

11:57 am
BE11:57am

No figures attached, so small one assumes, though Forbes seems to pin it at "upwards of £17.5m" ... https://www.forbes...ions/#7216fcf11421

BE12:00pm

So, I think we've run out of steam here.

12:00 pm
PM12:00pm

I think we have

PM12:00pm

Thanks for all that tho Bryce

PM12:00pm

Ad thanks for joining on the right

12:00 pm
PM12:00pm

PM12:00pm

BE11:30am

Coincidentally, Berenberg goes through the numbers on what's needed to push Provident into trouble.
